text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
I've got a new and improved recipe for a classic

Thai salad and that is glass noodle salad or yum woon 
sen now yum is a type of Thai salad and Woon sen is

glass noodles now to me this dish is the ultimate 
homesickness cure because it's one of those dishes

that you know we have all the time whether we're 
at home or in a restaurant and because it's so

easy to make this was one of the very first dishes 
I made when I first left home and I missed hai

food so I'm excited to share this recipe with you 
let's get started all right glass noodles you can

buy glass noodles of any Asian grocery stores 
and they come dry like this now this is actually

made of mung bean starch 100% mung bean starch 
so sometimes they'll be called bean threads or

bean vermicelli or glass vermicelli there's lots 
of different names for it so what you want to do

is get these soaking in just room-temperature 
water for about 10 minutes until they become

pliable like this I want to cut them just a couple 
of times so they're not too long so it's easier to

eat just with scissors all right so now the next 
thing you want to get going is the dried shrimp so

I've got here some dried shrimp which you can find 
at any Chinese grocery stores in the refrigerated

section there are many sizes I go for the medium 
one so what I did is I soaked them in hot water

just for five 10 minutes or so until they're nice 
and softened and you notice that they've sort of

swollen in size a little bit and that is so that 
I can pound them and break them up a little bit

so they'll distribute better if you don't have 
a mortar and pestle like this you can just chop

them just like that that's perfect so I'm going 
to just set this aside for now all right now the

dressing I'm going to add some garlic for a little 
pungent so just a couple of cloves here you can do

more if you'd like and spicy I always say there's 
no such thing as a Thai salad that's not spicy but

you can make this as spicy as you like I'm also 
going to add cilantro stems now the leaves and

say you tossin at the end but the stems are so 
aromatic and they make a great salad dressing

lots of cilantro if you don't like cilantro you 
can just leave it out I'm going to pound all

this into a paste all right just like that just 
a rough paste and now some sweetness to balance

I've got some palm sugar here you can just do a 
light brown sugar if you want and some people do

white sugar I used to do white sugar but I do find 
that palm sugar does add a little more complexity

and pound that until the sugar is dissolved just 
like that some salty of course fish sauce can't

have a tae-young without fish sauce and finally 
the last thing is fresh lime juice and I want to

stress the word fresh because bottled lime juices 
will not do it's the main ingredient you want the

salad to be tart and refreshing all right so my 
blanching water for the noodles and our protein

is going let's first look at the vegetables 
though I've got some onions here thinly sliced

now this is actually sweet onion because I think 
that's better for this dish I've got some tomatoes

you can use cherry I'm using roma tomatoes it's 
got lower moisture content so it won't release

too much water into the salad and I have some 
celery now normally I would use Chinese celery

but the Chinese celery at the store was no it 
was ridiculously wilted so I am using instead

the inner stalks of regular celery which works 
just as well so you know the inside stocks at a

lot of times you can't really use it for much but 
the leaves and the thinner stalks are perfect for

this dish so now in this mixing bowl I'm going to 
throw in my dried shrimp okay I think the water is

boiling now close enough what I love about yawen 
scent is that the wood scent takes literally two

minutes to cook all right so that's done now I'm 
actually going to remove them with tongs I want

to keep the water for my protein and when I get 
down to like the final strands I'm going to use

one of these handy things to try to get them all 
right with this water I'm going to turn it back on

and we'll cook my shrimp and you can also pan sear 
the shrimp if you want get little you know little

browning on them get a little extra flavor but 
I'm just going to keep it traditional and classic

in Thai cuisine we do blanch our protein quite 
a lot especially for salads so I don't need to

wait for the water to come to a full boil just 
a simmer is fine gentle cooking prevents shrimp

from overcooking too quickly and these will take 
literally 30 seconds okay and that's it for the

shrimp going to put them directly in my salad bowl 
here just make sure you shake off all the water

now what I'm going to do I've also got ground pork 
which I think it's the most important protein in

this dish you can do ground chicken if you'd like 
but I'm going to cook it in here but there's too

much water right now so I'm just going to pour 
off most of it until I only have just enough to

cover the bottom and if you've seen my lab video 
you recognize this technique as being a little

one and that means cooking something in just a 
little water or sometimes little oil until it's

fully cooked at the pork in there and I'm going 
to break that up really quickly so I don't get

big clumps I'm also going to add just a splash 
of fish sauce just a little bit to season the

pork and that's it once it's fully cooked you are 
done use a slotted skimmer or mesh skimmer and I'm

going to move that into my salad bowl there you go 
and the heats from the pork and the shrimp oyster

wilt the onions and tomatoes and celery a little 
bit and that's a good thing now what I'm going

to do is I'm going to add some of that cooking 
liquid because that is like pork stock now it's

got pork flavor and shrimp flavor and I think it 
sort of brings everything together not too much

just about a tablespoon you don't want to you know 
dilute the dressing okay the noodles go in the

dressing is going to go directly on the noodles 
and that will help the noodle split up oh that

smells so good right now just look at that oh I'm 
also going to add now the cilantro leaves and use

the stem for the dressing and use the leaves for 
the salad there we go that looks and smells like

a party and young Winston is just one of those 
dishes you want to eat as soon as it's done okay

because the noodles will continue to absorb the 
dressing and then it'll be dry and the noodles

will be all swollen so you don't want to toss it 
till you're ready to rock look at that look how

pretty that is now I am not quite done yet this 
is only gonna get better with a little crunch I

am adding some roasted peanuts and I roasted the 
peanuts fresh it's going to be that nutty crunchy

element of the salad and that is what's going 
to make it perfect if you're allergic to nuts

you can do pumpkin seeds or or soy nuts cashews 
will work as well but peanuts are my favorite for

this all right so normally I like to eat this 
with rice but you can serve it as an appetizer

on its own I don't have any rice right now so I'm 
going to eat it on its own make sure it gets some

dried shrimp on theirs and peanuts on there oh my 
gosh oh this smell this makes me this home already

oh my Garf that's the flavor of Thailand right 
there when I think of Thai food this is the flavor

that comes to my a balance of sweet salty and sour 
but it leads with sour so refreshing the celery's

crunchy the tomato is juicy and the noodles if 
you haven't had glass noodles before they have the

funnest texture the peanuts really add that crunch 
and nuttiness oh my God if you haven't tried yet

within you have to try it and if you've tried my 
old recipe try this one this is even better so

the recipe as always will be out hot Thai Kitchen 
calm when you make it send me a photo on Facebook

Twitter or Instagram if you haven't subscribed 
to the show you know what to do subscribe so

you'll never miss an episode and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai
